children: Spondyloarthritis comprises several systemic inflammatory joint disorders that share distinct clinical, radiographic, and genetic features. The spondyloarthritis disorders are:
asymmetric inflammation in ≤4 peripheral joints (typically large joints)
inflammation at the sites of ligament and tendon insertion (enthesitis)
extra-articular conditions, such as aortitis, colitis, urethritis, uveitis, and psoriasis
HLA-B*27 testing may support, but cannot independently confirm or exclude, a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis or other forms of spondyloarthritis.

Patients may also have psoriasiform lesions on palms and soles (keratoderma blennorrhagicum) or glans penis (circinate balanitis).
Antibiotic treatment of reactive arthritis caused by enteric organisms is not usually warranted.

In the absence of an ongoing infection, reactive arthritis is usually self-limited, and symptoms resolve within 6 months; select symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs and glucocorticoid injections for these patients with mild disease.
The classic triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis (or cervicitis) is found in only one third of patients with reactive arthritis.
Do not prescribe chronic antibiotic therapy for patients with reactive arthritis.
A 33-year-old man has a 3-month history of left shoulder and right ankle pain and a left inflamed second toe. He had 4 days of bloody diarrhea 3 months ago.
For diagnosis, choose reactive arthritis, consistent with a previous enteric infection.

Ankylosing spondylitis primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. It also may involve the shoulders and hips. The small peripheral joints are not affected. Ankylosing spondylitis occurs most often in patients <45 years and presents as chronic inflammatory low back pain (more than 1 hour of morning stiffness).
Characteristic symptoms are pain and stiffness that worsen at night and are relieved with physical activity or heat.
decreased hyperextension, forward flexion, lateral flexion, and axial rotation
enthesitis of the plantar fascia and Achilles tendon insertion

Extra-articular manifestations include acute anterior uveitis (most common), aortic valvular regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, cardiac conduction defects, apical pulmonary fibrosis and cavitation, and cauda equina syndrome.
A patient with ankylosing spondylitis with increased pain and mobility of the neck following a minor accident may have a fracture and requires an urgent CT of the cervical spine.
For patients with normal or nondiagnostic plain x-rays of the spine and sacroiliac joints, a positive result on HLA-B*27 testing can be useful for deciding to pursue advanced imaging.

X-rays of the sacroiliac joints show sacroiliitis with erosions, pseudowidening of the joints, sclerosis, and ankylosis. X-rays of the spine show subchondral bony sclerosis, vertebral body squaring, and bony ankylosis (“bamboo spine”).
When radiographic findings are equivocal or absent, MRI can detect the early changes of sacroiliitis.
Ankylosing spondylitis occurs in both men and women.
HLA-B*27 is never diagnostic but can help determine risk for spondyloarthritis in uncertain situations.
Select exercise to preserve range of motion and strengthen the spine extensor muscles to prevent kyphosis.
continuous NSAIDs (not aspirin) (disease modifying in ankylosing spondylitis)
glucocorticoid injections for recalcitrant enthesitis and persistent synovitis
TNF inhibitors if inadequate response of axial disease to NSAIDs
Do not prescribe methotrexate, sulfasalazine, or hydroxychloroquine for patients with axial disease because they are ineffective. Select a TNF inhibitor.
A 40-year-old man with ankylosing spondylitis has increasing neck pain after a fall from the second rung of a ladder 5 days ago.
For diagnosis, choose acute cervical fracture. For management, select neck immobilization and emergent CT.
Ankylosing spondyloarthritis, isolated sacroiliitis, and peripheral arthritis occur in patients with Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis.

For spondyloarthritis associated with bowel involvement, medications to address peripheral arthritis and bowel inflammation include sulfasalazine, azathioprine, methotrexate, and glucocorticoids. The TNF inhibitors are especially useful for bowel and joint symptoms, including spine disease.
